docs.lead_paragraph: The Food and Drug Administration approved a new inhaled drug today for treating influenza, overriding a panel of independent scientific advisers who recommended five months ago that the drug be kept off pharmacy shelves because it is only marginally effective and may be dangerous for asthma patients. The drug, Relenza, made by Glaxo Wellcome PLC, brings to three the number of antiviral medications available to treat the flu. Relenza is the first medicine approved to treat both Type A and Type B strains of influenza, as opposed to Type A only, and it is the first in a new class of drugs that block the spread of the flu throughout the body by inhibiting an enzyme called neuraminidase.

headline.main: Federal Agency Approves Anti-Flu Drug, Overriding Expert Panel's Recommendation

docs.abstract: Food and Drug Administration approves Relenza, inhaled drug for treating influenza, overriding expert panel's finding that drug is only marginally effective and may be dangerous for asthma patients; drug, made by Glaxo Wellcome PLC, is first in new class of drugs that block spread of flu throughout body by inhibiting enzyme neuraminidase (M)
docs.snippet: The Food and Drug Administration approved a new inhaled drug today for treating influenza, overriding a panel of independent scientific advisers who recommended five months ago that the drug be kept off pharmacy shelves because it is only marginally...

docs.lead_paragraph: In the midst of the bitter debate this week over the Republican tax bills moving through Congress, it was easy to lose sight of the emerging consensus in both parties that there should be a tax cut this year. The question now is where the middle ground on taxes might be and how the White House and Congress can get there.

headline.main: Seeking Common Ground on Federal Tax Cut

docs.snippet: In the midst of the bitter debate this week over the Republican tax bills moving through Congress, it was easy to lose sight of the emerging consensus in both parties that there should be a tax cut this year.    The question now is where the middle...

docs.lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL A2-7 Leader of China Movement Seeks Talks with Beijing The leader of the fast-spreading spiritual Falun Gong movement, which was banned by the Chinese Government, said his group had no political ambitions and he called for dialogue with the Government. A3 The Government continued its campaign of invective against Falun Gong. There was a tight cordon of security in central Beijing, where members of the group had gathered in protest after the authorities began detaining movement leaders around the country on Monday. A3

docs.lead_paragraph: The secret to happiness, it turns out, may not be wealth or power. Or love or success or faithful friendship. Or Ray Charles crooning ''Georgia on My Mind'' or even chocolate mousse. Finding happiness may mean going no further than your very own forehead -- the left prefrontal cortex of your brain, to be exact. The more the sparks fly from this sliver of gray matter, the more electrical impulses it generates, the happier you are.

headline.main: Looking for Happiness? It May Be Very Near; When the Heart Sings, Part of the Cortex Gets Busy

docs.abstract: Researchers find that happiness may be a function of activity in prefontal cortex of brain--that the more sparks fly from this area of brain, the more electrical impulses it generates, the happier a person is; that is conclusion of Richard J Davidson, professor of psychology and psychiatry at University of Wisconsin, and others who have examined adults, children, infants, even Rhesus monkeys; over several years, they have tested perky, enthusiastic people, and pessimistic, morose ones, and results are always the same: people blessed with effervescent left prefrontal cortices are much more likely to be smiling; photos (L)
docs.snippet: The secret to happiness, it turns out, may not be wealth or power. Or love or success or faithful friendship. Or Ray Charles crooning ''Georgia on My Mind'' or even chocolate mousse.     Finding happiness may mean going no further than your very own...

docs.lead_paragraph: The female condom, seldom used in the West, is catching on here and in many parts of the developing world, slowly becoming an important new weapon in the fight against the AIDS epidemic. Nearly seven million have been distributed in 34 countries in Africa, Asia and Latin America, and the device is gaining acceptance among men as well as women.

headline.main: Condoms for Women Gain Approval Among Africans

docs.abstract: Female condom, seldom used in West, is catching on in South Africa, finding favor with men as well as women, and it is slowly becoming an important new weapon in fight against AIDS epidemic; United Nations AIDS and other organizations working to persuade more women to try the female condom are first approaching prostitutes and other women with multiple partners, since persuading them to use condoms has notably reduced rates of AIDS infection; female condom, properly used, is believed to be as good as or better than the male condom at preventing infection and is slightly less effective than male condom at preventing pregnancy; photo (M)
docs.snippet: The female condom, seldom used in the West, is catching on here and in many parts of the developing world, slowly becoming an important new weapon in the fight against the AIDS epidemic.     Nearly seven million have been distributed in 34 countries...

docs.lead_paragraph: A New York City Police Department policy that took effect this week has some officers wondering whether poppy seed bagels are now as off-limits to them as heroin, graft or consorting with organized crime figures. The policy, which prohibits police officers from using commercial products that may contain illegal drugs or their derivatives, was intended, in part, to make it more difficult for police officers who test positive for drug use to argue that their test results were skewed by their use of certain foods, health care products or cosmetics.

headline.main: New Police Drug Policy Takes On Hemp Oil

docs.abstract: New York City Police Dept officials say new policy, which prohibits officers from using commercial products that may contain illegal drugs or their derivatives, was intended, in part, to make it more difficult for officers who test positive for drug use to argue that their test results were skewed by their use of products; Patrolmen's Benevolent Association denounces new policy (M)
